title: Opening Your First Account
description: Choose between Canada's Big 5 banks and credit unions based on your needs.

content.title: Big 5 Banks vs. Credit Unions
content.text: The 'Big 5' (RBC, TD, Scotiabank, BMO, CIBC) are for-profit and offer massive national ATM networks. Credit unions are not-for-profit and member-owned, often providing lower fees and more personalized, community-focused service.

content.title: Convenience vs. Cost
content.text: Big banks provide advanced mobile apps and comprehensive products, but often require a high minimum balance (e.g., $4,000) to waive fees. Credit unions generally offer higher interest rates on savings and lower fees, but have fewer physical branches.

content.title: Safety and Networks
content.text: Your money is safe in both! Banks are insured federally by the CDIC up to $100k, while credit unions have comparable provincial insurance. Credit union members can often use 'THE EXCHANGE Network' to access thousands of surcharge-free ATMs across Canada.

quiz.question: Which institution is most likely to waive monthly fees based on a high minimum balance requirement?
quiz.explanation: Big 5 banks typically have monthly fees that can only be waived if you maintain a specific minimum balance, such as $4,000 to $6,000.

quiz.question: True or False: Credit unions are owned by their members rather than outside shareholders.
quiz.explanation: True! Credit unions are not-for-profit organizations owned by members, which allows them to return profits in the form of lower fees and better interest rates.
